members.name: Jean-Pierre Antikidis
members.description: Former head of Space System Information at CNES and international expert in Space Data management

experience.item: Managed ground systems projects for Pakistan, Africa, and Asia, and spent 8 years at the European Space Agency.
Responsible at CNES for concepts of future ground systems and French delegate in scientific and technical advisory groups.
Inventor of advanced computing technologies, part of the initial group that conceived what is now known as the Cloud.

members.currentRole: President and CEO of Blue Planet. Leads the technical development of the v-GLOBE program since 2009, focusing on space sensors, telecommunications, and Cloud systems.

members.name: Patrice Brudieu
members.description: Former Deputy Director at CNES and adviser at the French Ministry of Space Policy.

experience.item: Worked at CNES as a system engineer in Earth observation satellites, and later Deputy Director in charge of program management, valorization, and defense affairs.
Held key responsibilities at the European Space Agency (ESA) within the manned flight program.
Led the ministerial department responsible for the French Space Policy for six years, gaining high-level strategic insight into European and French space organizations.
Advisor to Blue Planet on technical, managerial, and funding strategies for EO-based programs and satellite infrastructure.

members.currentRole: Senior project adviser to Blue Planet, supporting strategic development and partnerships in the European space ecosystem.

members.name: Bernard Plano
members.description: Senior aerospace and defense executive, former CEO of Matra Systems & Information, and international business strategist

experience.item: Electrical engineer with an MBA from HEC Business School.
Joined Matra/EADS in the late 1980s, specialized in data systems for defense; led Matra Systems & Information as Chairman & CEO (1996–2004).
Executive VP of International Business Development at EADS, with responsibility for defense and space systems in over 50 countries.
Founded Plano BP Consulting and led strategic international development at Spacebel, a leader in European space information systems.
Oversaw major European space programs like Ariane, SPOT, Helios, and Hipparcos.

members.currentRole: Industrial team manager at Blue Planet since 2012, guiding team management and supplier networks, and supporting the company’s strategic and financial evolution.

members.name: Michel Courtois
members.role: CTO – Head of Space Segment Engineering
members.description: Former Director at ESA/ESTEC and SPOT satellite program lead engineer at CNES

experience.item: Graduated from École Polytechnique and ENSAE in 1971 as an aerospace engineer.
Led the development of the French Earth Observation SPOT satellite at CNES, launched in 1986, laying the foundation for European commercial EO programs.
Held leadership roles at CNES including Deputy Director for applications and Director of the Toulouse Space Center.
Appointed CTO and Vice President of Alcatel Space, managing over 1500 engineers in charge of technical development and quality.
Served as Director of Technical and Quality Management at ESA and Head of ESTEC (2004–2010).
Recipient of numerous awards, including the Legion of Honour (2000), National Order of Merit (1991), and the Grand Prix of ANAE (1987).

members.currentRole: President of the Van Allen Foundation and CTO of Blue Planet for the v-GLOBE space segment, overseeing quality and technical performance.

services.title: Early Warning
services.description: Prediction of floods, wildfires, and disease outbreaks. Satellite remote sensing provides a comprehensive view of climate patterns, soil temperature, and other environmental factors that help forecast extreme events. This information is crucial for disaster planning and response.
features: Global, continuous temporal coverage via satellite constellations
Automated data processing with anomaly detection
Multisensor integration (optical, radar, radiometric) for greater reliability
Timely communication with alerts scalable to the level of risk
services.text: Early warning through Earth Observation involves continuous monitoring of critical environmental variables—such as soil moisture, gas concentrations, vegetation cover and water levels—to detect early signals of potential natural disasters. This method not only improves the accuracy of forecasts for wildfires, droughts, floods and landslides, but also optimizes how resources are allocated for risk reduction. Integrating meteorological, geochemical and topographic data enables early warning systems to help local authorities and civil‐protection agencies anticipate extreme events, plan evacuations and reinforce critical infrastructure in advance.
